references.text: A classic example of this arises when solving differential equations by difference techniques. If the basic spacing chosen for the difference apprοximation is too large one can get false answers. For example, when solving the differential equation of an undamped second order system (linear oscillator), too large a spacing will cause the introduction of damping and a decrease in the natural frequency of oscillation. See the Houbolt approximation in the following book: Levy, S. and Kroll, W.: "Errors Introduced by Finite Space and Time Increments in Dynamic Response Calculations," Proceedings of the First National Congress of Applied Mechanics, pp. 1-9 (1951).

references.text: This equation can also be written as: (α02 — α42)2 > (α0α3—α1α4)2, or equivalently [α0A3 > α4B3]. If we let α4 be positive (as we always can by multiplying F(z) by minus sign), then this relationship is written in the form [(α0 / α4)Α3 > Β3](2a). Furthermore, (1), (2) or 2a) and (3) in this case are now equivalent to the constraint:, | A1 | < | B1 |, B3 < 0, and | Α3 | < | B3 |. Therefore, it is shown that for stability test of the fourth-order case, the determinant for obtaining (2) is redundant. Since we have let α4 > 0, the auxiliary constraint for this case is then (4). This simplification can be extended to the general case where it can be shown that the number of the determinant for obtaining the A's and the B's can be reduced. However, its derivation is deferred to a future discussion. It might be noted, however, that this additional simplification is similar to the Liénard-Chipart criterion [3] for the continuous case.

references.text: O(Δ) is used for terms of smaller order than Δ.
If α were not replaced by the additive process z, there would be the temptation to write (g+α)Δ, a meaningless symbol, instead of gΔ+Δzt.

For (4) to have meaning, the system must have the following "Μarkοvian" property: There exists a set of observable quantities x(t) (called state variables or "sυfficient statistics) so that, no matter how the system evolved up to time t, the expected value of the integral in (2), conditioned upon all observable information up to t, equals (with probability one) the expected value conditioned upon x(t). This expected value should be a(unique) function of x(t) and t only. The form of (1) and the assumption of independent increments in z, and knowledge of the covariance of Δzt, certainly assure the satisfaction of those conditions when the x are the phase variables of the system (1). Often (for example, when the covariance of Δzt is a random variable the state space must be further enlarged and additional quantities observed, but this will not be pursued further here. The fundamental point is that (4) and its derivatives are valid for any x vector that is a continuous Markov process with mean drift rate g and covariance components [illegible text]ij. The assumptions concerning the form of (1) and the zt process were made purely for convenience. In a more general stochastic control problem, one must find a Markovian system that represents the stochastic system and this Markovian system will usually include variables other than those defined by the differential equation.

It should be borne in mind that (6) and (7) yield the correct solution (numerical or analytical) only if pijk is bounded in every region through which the point (x,t) may pass. This is not always the case as often, for example, when the control is discontinuous ("bang-bang"). In this case, since (6) still has a local validity, it will still yield much useful information (such as the form of the control) and may often be used for local constructions of the control. Discussions of the corresponding problem in the deterministic case are given by Kalman2 and Rosonoer1 (part 3).
This particular problem is often easily solved analytically using the method outlined by Rosonoer,1 (part 1).

context.text: We propose to develop a spatially adaptive speckle-reduction algorithm by fusing the wavelet Bayesian denoising technique [11] with an image regularization procedure based on Markov random fields.

Under certain conditions [12], [13], speckle in SAR images is generally assumed to be fully developed and modeled as multiplicative random noise, whereas most of the existing wavelet denoising algorithms are developed for additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) [11], [14]–[16], as additive noise is most common in imaging and sensing systems.
Most early models [11], [16] assumed the wavelet coefficients to be independently distributed.

In order to cast the estimation problem into a mathematically friendly environment, a mixture density model has been recently proposed as a prior to statistically model the wavelet coefficients [11], [30].

Applying a mixture of two Gaussian distributions with one mixture component corresponding to insignificant coefficients (representing “homogeneity”), and the other to significant coefficients (representing “heterogeneity”), Chipman [11] reconstructed the noise-free signal as a nonlinear rescaling of noisy measurements using a simple but elegant closed-form representation.

To better model the wavelet coefficients, it has been proposed [11], [30] and demonstrated that using a mixture density of two normal distributions with zero mean can provide a fairly accurate approximation to the distribution of wavelet coefficients of natural images.

In general, the Bayesian solution will end up with a continuous shrinking function imposed on noisy observations, in contrast with the thresholding method, which usually involves a binary thresholding action.

context.text: The two unsupervised feature extraction algorithms that we used were the projection pursuit (PP) algorithm described in [8] and the well-known principal component analysis (PCA) algorithm [47] that is popular in the remote sensing literature (e.g., see [23] and [44], and many others).

PCA uses the directions of maximal variance and derives an orthonormal set of basis vectors to identify significant structure in the data; these views of the data are not always easily interpreted with respect to specific underlying categories because of the orthogonality requirement [7], [8], [14].

In contrast, PP [7] [8]–[10], [12], [20], [21], [46] uses higher order statistical information to overcome this difficulty and identify directions in which the projected data distribution (view) is non-Gaussian or multimodal.
Only within the last ten years has PP been applied in the field of remote sensing (see [2]–[5], [7], [8], [25], [29], and [30]) and in other disciplines (see [19], [26], [33], and [34]).
The PP algorithm described in [8] (the PP algorithm used in this paper) is based on an algorithm originally proposed in [20].

However, in [8], projections are optimized simultaneously rather than in residual subspaces, as is sometimes the case in PP algorithms [21], [24], and projections are nonlinear, in order to remove sensitivity to outliers, rather than the linear form found in [20].
Although further details are provided in [8], the basic idea is that a cost function, emphasizing both intracluster spread and compactness within each cluster, is to be optimized.

While the approach that we defined in [8] does not specifically aim to derive an orthonormal PP filter set, it did incorporate a mechanism for decorrelating projections in the stochastic optimization process.
Additional implementation details can be found in [6] and [8].

The PP algorithm described in [8] (the PP algorithm used in this paper) is based on an algorithm originally proposed in [20].

However, in [8], projections are optimized simultaneously rather than in residual subspaces, as is sometimes the case in PP algorithms [21], [24], and projections are nonlinear, in order to remove sensitivity to outliers, rather than the linear form found in [20].

The Friedman–Tukey Projection Index [20], \$I\$, on which our projection index is based, was the product of a trimmed variance \$S\$ and a compactness function \$N\$where \$c_{k}(\mu)\$ is the \$k\$th data projection of the \$\mu\$th sample vector, denoted \$\vec {f}(\mu)\$, and unit projection vector \${\mathhat {w}}_{k}\$; \$\theta\$ is a step function; \$R\$ is a scalar compactness or cluster scale; \$g(r_{k}(\mu,\nu))\$ is a monotonically decreasing function of the distance between projected sample pairs \$r_{k}(\mu,\nu)\$; \$M_{p}\$ is the number of samples; and \$m\$ the number of outliers removed in the trimmed variance.

To develop our automatic land cover classification models, we chose a somewhat different approach, attempting to achieve species-level classification in many instances, while considering in some cases plant communities that were similar to those described in [35].

However, for purposes of this introduction, we have grouped the land cover into five or six principal categories, some of which equate to those described in [35], while others are aggregates of several of these categories.

The high salinity tends to kill off most vegetation, and typically only the most salt-tolerant plants such as Salicornia virginica will survive in small clumps; wash flats are often predecessors of salt pannes [35].

Many of the categories, such as Myrica cerifera Thicket, Distichlis spicata, Spartina alterniflora, Backdune vegetation, “Wrack” (Fig. 2) appear to have produced consistent results based on our field observations and historical data [32], [35].

context.text: In all supervised clasification models considered in this paper, the final stage of classification was a variant of the backward propagation of error model [41] with a cross-entropy cost function (BPCE) [40].

We use the cross-entropy cost function because it is less prone to local minima than the originally proposed least mean-square (LMS) error [40], owing to the form of the gradient used in the stochastic gradient descent.

context.text: In some CDMA signal environments, when the desired signal at the output of the despreader is sufficiently larger than each of the interferers with the aid of a large processing gain [3], [15], the weight vector obtained from the criterion of the maximum signal-to-noise ratio (MSNR) can be a good substitution for that of the MSINR.
Then, as shown in [3] and [15], a computationally efficient adaptive algorithm for a blind beamforming can be derived.
It particularly means that the final array output for extracting the signal from each user is produced by combining \$K_{j}\$ array outputs [3].

As described in [3], the array system that processes each of the multipaths separately outperforms the array system that processes the received signals of each user with a single multibeam, although it is a burden in the former system that the computation of each weight vector separately for each corresponding path is inevitable.

Note that if spread signals behave random signals and angles of arrival (AOAs) of received signal vectors are sufficiently uniformly distributed, we can assume that \${\bf R}_{xx}\$ is a diagonal matrix so that (19) becomes [3]
.

Since it has already been found in [3] that the weight vector based on the MSNR criterion enhances the receiving performance of CDMA systems quite considerably, the simulations given in this paper have been focused on the cases when the proposed algorithm, which is based on the MSINR criterion, outperforms the solution of the MSNR [3].
As mentioned in Section III, the proposed algorithm finds the solution of the generalized eigenproblem, while the method introduced in [3] provides the solution of the ordinary eigenproblem.

As is well described in [3]and [15], the solution of the ordinary eigenproblem is valid only when the desired signal power is sufficiently larger than the interfering power because the eigenvector corresponding to the largest eigenvalue of the ordinary eigenproblem makes sense only in that signal environment.

From the various computer simulations, it has been found that the proposed array system outperforms the array system designed by the solution of the ordinary eigenproblem [3], especially when the interfering power increases due to many practical reasons, e.g., incorrect power control, various spreading ratio, various transmitting power, too many interferers, etc.

θ and φ polarizations correspond to the vertical and horizontal polarizations used in [9] in the plane perpendicular to the incidence angle.

context.text: A system concept for third-generation mobile radio systems, which in the meantime entered the standardization process of European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI), is the time division–code-division multiple access (TD-CDMA) concept investigated at the Research Group for RF Communications, University of Kaiserslautern, Germany, in cooperation with Siemens AG since the early 1990s [1], [2].
A main feature of this multiple-access scheme is the application of joint detection techniques in the receiver in order to combat intracell multiple access interference [2].

Concerning power control, a slow algorithm which compensates only shadowing and not fast fading is sufficient, since joint detection CDMA, in contrast to conventional CDMA applying single-user detection, does not suffer from intracell multiple-access interference [2].

Since the uplink is the more critical link—at least in a single-cell environment—the measurements performed with the TD-CDMA hardware demonstrator, like corresponding simulations [2], [4], [5], [7], [12], can be restricted to the uplink.

Each burst contains a transmitter specific midamble with \$L_{\rm m}\$ chips for channel estimation in the receiver [4].

The required \$K_{\rm m}\$ different midambles are derived from a basic midamble code \${\underline{\mmb{m}}}\$ of length \$K_{{\rm m}\max} \cdot W\$, where \$K_{{\rm m}\max}\$ is the maximum number of mobiles, and \$W\$ is the expected maximum number of taps of the channel impulse responses [4].

The user-specific midamble code \${\underline{\mmb{m}}}^{(m)}\$ is obtained by rotating the basic midamble code right by \$W \cdot m\$ chips and periodic expansion to \$L_{\rm m} \geq (K_{{\rm m}\max}+1)W-1\$ chips [4].

In the receiver, only that part of the received signal, which exclusively results from the transmitted midambles, i.e., which contains no interference from the adjacent data blocks, is fed into the channel estimator [4].

context.text: A number of previous works use the notion of azimuth spread in the modeling of the spatial channel, from a Gaussian distribution of power across azimuth [8] to uniform distribution of power over a fixed span of azimuth [9]–[10][11].
A model suggested by [10] assumes scatterers in a circular area, spread over some span of azimuth as viewed by the receiver antenna array.
However, in the model of [10], a uniform distribution of scatterer azimuths is imposed as in [11], and the underlying physical distribution of scatterers is lost.

Further, the Doppler shifts for the scatters in the model of [10] are not chosen based on an underlying physical distribution, but to ultimately obtain the classic Doppler spectrum in the received signal.

context.text: Several stopping criteria have been devised [3], [12].
Both the sign change and bit-matching (BM) criteria proposed in [12] are more computationally efficient than the cross-entropy (CE) criterion proposed in [3].
The BM criterion of [12] can be applied to terminate decoding in parallel mode in a straightforward manner.

However, to test the CE criterion at each iteration, it requires a total of 5\$K-\$1 real number operations, including 2\$K-\$1 additions and subtractions, 2\$K\$ multiplications and divisions, and \$K\$ exponentiations [12].
Using the BM stopping criterion [12], if \$\mathhat{\bf V}^{(1)}_2\$ and \$\mathhat{\bf V}^{(2)}_2\$ match in every bit position, the turbo-decoding iteration process can be stopped.

To show the effectiveness of the SM criterion, we stop the inner turbo-decoding iteration with four stopping criteria: 1) a fixed number of iterations \${}=10\$, 2) the CE criterion [3], 3) the BM criterion [12], and 4) the SM criterion.

context.text: However, with an eye toward the future, where 4G cellular systems will require very large bandwidth to support anticipated 60-Mb/s data rates (see, e.g., [15]), it will not be possible to support all carriers in a single antenna array (due to the different beam patterns that would result from the different carriers).

Moreover, in future-generation systems that will operate over noncontiguous frequency bands (e.g., see [15]) and those that will support ultra-wide-band (UWB) communications, a constant beam pattern over the range of transmit frequencies can only be achieved with \$P > 1\$.

For example, if we imagine a future-generation system with a 100-MHz bandwidth to support the anticipated 60-Mb/s data rate (per user) of 4G (see, e.g., [15]), and we assume transmission at, e.g., 4 GHz, then maximum frequency separation is 0.025 of the carrier frequency, and we require three unique antenna arrays to create identical beam patterns on each antenna array.

Referring the reader to [18] and [19] for a detailed presentation, we provide a brief discussion elaborating on how small beam-pattern movement \$(\kappa < 0.05)\$ can lead to large time diversity gain \$(L \approx 7)\$.
Specifically, small beam-pattern movement over \$T_S\$ leads to, e.g., seven different gains and phase offsets over \$T_S\$ (see [18] and [19]).

Specifically, based on our earlier work in [18] and [19], we demonstrated that a seven-fold diversity benefit is achieved in a mid-sized city center (three scatterers per 1000 m2) assuming \$\kappa = 0.05\$ (i.e., beam-pattern movement corresponds to 5% of the HPBW), BS–mobile distance \$x_o = 1000\$ m, and HPBW\$~ = 0.3\$ rad (i.e., HPBW\$~ \approx 18^{\circ}\$).

context.text: Previous work on LMMSE receivers for one-shot bit symbol detection in asynchronous random-CDMA can be found in [10]–[12][14].
The work in [11]–[12][14], on the other hand, focuses on band-limited chip waveforms under the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel.

The work of [11] presents a discrete-time correlator, which approximates the continuous-time correlator of the LMMSE receiver in [12], [13], and analyzes the receiver performance in terms of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and near–far efficiency (NFE) as the figures of merit.

In contrast, the work of [12], [13] derives an exact and explicit formulation of the frequency response of the LMMSE receiver and examines its performance according to probability of bit error [12] and outage probability [13] criteria.
The intent of this paper is to generalize the work of [12], [13], which originally considered the AWGN channel, to multipath channels.
The design approach is similar to that of [12]–[14] except for generalizing the AWGN channel to the multipath channel.
The method of solving for \$h_n(t)\$ from the integral equation in (11) follows that of [12], [13].

Flight path in radiation pattern measurements


In the past aeronautical satellite communications experiments in the \$L\$-band [7], we observed signal power fluctuations of 3 to 4 dB, which were caused by interference between the direct wave and the waves reflected from the main wing of the aircraft.
Since the beam width of the \$L\$-band phased-array antenna of [7] is much broader than that of the \$Ka\$-band antenna, waves reflected off the aircraft may be easily received.

A very successful architecture for such AHSs has been shown to be the operation of vehicles in “platoons” with very small constant spacing between the cars in the platoon and with the existence of wireless radio communication between the cars in the platoon [3], [5].
The lower level controller determines the throttle and/or brake commands required to track the desired acceleration [3]–[5].

context.text: The Nakagami distribution [4] is chosen to model the fading experienced by the desired, delayed, and interfering signals because of its versatility and flexibility in modeling various fading environments.

The complex envelope of the signal is where \$\theta_{ik}\$ is the \$k\$th symbol of the \$i\$th subcarrier, \$T\$ is the symbol interval, and \$p(t)\$ is the impulse response of the transmitter raised-cosine filter given by The \$i\$th transmitted signal is modulated by a Nakagami envelope whose probability density function (pdf) is given as [4] where \$\Gamma(\,{\cdot}\,)\$ is the Gamma function. \$\Omega\$ controls the spread of the distribution and \$m\$ is the shape factor or the fading parameter, as defined in [4].
The resultant interfering signal has a zero mean and a variance \$\sigma_c^2={L^2\Omega_c}/2\$ [4].

context.text: It has been argued elsewhere [1] that often the most efficient FPGA implementation of an algorithm is one which supports a wide variety of finite precision representations, so that the best representation can be used for each internal variable.

The wordlength optimization techniques of interest are those which allow a user-controlled trade-off between implementation area and signal quality at the DSP system outputs, such as those described by [1], [3], [4], [5].
The Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) technique described in this paper has been applied to several small benchmark circuits, and the results compared to the heuristic presented in [1].
Those offering an area/signal quality trade-off are all of an heuristic nature [1], [3], [5] or do not support different fractional precision for different internal variables [4].
In a previous paper [1] we present an optimization heuristic based on analytic average-case error analysis of LTI systems.
The algorithms described by computation graphs will be implemented using a multiple wordlength architecture, asix introduced in [1].
A total of \$m\$ bits may not be required due to signal scaling information [1].
Instead we propose to use a ‘coefficient blind’ area model, which has been demonstrated in practice to provide good results [1], [15], [17].
As shown in [1], since the systems of interest for this work have the LTI property, an analytic model based on [19] can be used to estimate the error at each system output.

Our bounding procedure proceeds in three stages: perform an heuristic wordlength optimization on the computation graph [1]; use the resulting area as an upper-bound on the area of each gain block within the system, and hence on the input wordlength of each gain block; ‘condition’ the graph, following the procedure of [1].

Signal \$o\$ is the output signal for the adder and \$m_{v}\$ models the number of MSBs of the addition which are known through scaling to contain no information, as described in [1] and illustrated in Fig. 3.

Three curves are present in each plot: the optimum uniform wordlength implementation, the heuristically derived multiple wordlength implementation from [1], and the optimum multiple wordlength implementation achieved by solving the MILP presented in this paper.
An optimum wordlength allocation for an RGB to YCrCb convertor described in [1] with 4-bit inputs has also been performed.
This result shows an optimal cost of 78.61 LUTs, equal to the result achieved by the heuristic presented in [1].
We believe such optimum results, even for small circuits, to be highly valuable as a benchmark against which many new and existing heuristics [1], [3], [4], [5], [8], [9], [10] may be compared.
Results indicate that our previously proposed heuristic solution [1] produces results reaching the optimum in most cases and, on average, deviating only 0.7% from the optimum area.

context.text: The wordlength optimization techniques of interest are those which allow a user-controlled trade-off between implementation area and signal quality at the DSP system outputs, such as those described by [1], [3], [4], [5].
Those offering an area/signal quality trade-off are all of an heuristic nature [1], [3], [5] or do not support different fractional precision for different internal variables [4].

context.text: Recently, the floating-point units of several commercial processors include a floating-point multiply-add-fused (MAF) unit [2], [7], [9], which executes the double-precision multiply-add \$A+(B\times C)\$ as a single instruction.

This fused implementation has two advantages: (1) the operation is performed with only one rounding instead of two and (2) there is reduction in the delay and hardware required by sharing several components [2].
The MAF architecture proposed before [3], implemented in several floating-point units units of general-purpose processors [2], [3], [7], is shown in Figure 1(a).
To obtain a faster implementation of the basic MAF, the adder is implemented as a 161–bit one's complement adder with an end–around–carry adjustment [2], [3], [7].
According to [2], the delay of the normalization shifter is about 40% of the delay of the 106–bits 1's complement adder, \$t_{norm\ sh}\approx 10\ t_{nd2}\$ ·.

Table 5 provides a comparison of the proposed method with the previous approaches in concurrent test of analog circuits [2], [3], [5] in terms of fault coverage (FC), hardware overhead (HO) and performance overhead (PO).

Since scanty detailed data for fault coverage is provided in [3], [5], a fault coverage comparison can be made only in terms of the percentage of the components, the deviation in which result in a failure alarm.

Hardware overhead and performance overhead of both methods presented in [2], [3] and [5] cannot be controlled; the method presented in [2], [3] requires observation of all state variables some of which may not be physically accessible.
